title: Week 5: Basic Syntax
text:
Equal to

1 == 1 # is 1 equal to 1?

[1] TRUE

1 == 2 # is 1 equal to 2?

[1] FALSE

c(1, 2, 3) == c(2, 1, 3) # compares each element with each element

[1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE

1 == c(2, 1, 3)

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE


###Not Equal to

1 != 1 # is 1 equal to 1?

[1] FALSE

1 != 2 # is 1 equal to 2?

[1] TRUE

c(1, 2, 3) != c(2, 1, 3) # compares each element with each element

[1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE

1 != c(2, 1, 3)

[1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE


###Greater than or less than

1 > 1 # is 1 greater than 1?

[1] FALSE

5 > 1 # is 5 greater than 1?

[1] TRUE

3 < 2 # is 3 less than 2?

[1] FALSE

3 < 1 # is 3 less than 1?

[1] FALSE

c(1, 2, 3) > c(2, 1, 3) # ask the question element by element

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE

c(1, 2, 3) < c(2, 1, 3)

[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE

2 > c(1, 2, 3) # is greater than each of the numbers

[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE




Greater than or Equal to, Less than or Equal to

1 >= 1 # is 1 greater than 1?

[1] TRUE

5 >= 1 # is 5 greater than 1?

[1] TRUE

3 <= 2 # is 3 less than 2?

[1] FALSE

3 <= 1 # is 3 less than 1?

[1] FALSE

c(1, 2, 3) >= c(2, 1, 3) # ask the question element by element

[1] FALSE  TRUE  TRUE

c(1, 2, 3) <= c(2, 1, 3)

[1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE

2 >= c(1, 2, 3) # is greater than each of the numbers

[1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE


###And

 #is 16 divisible by 4 AND 8
16 %% 4 == 0 & 16 %% 8 == 0

[1] TRUE

# is 16 divisible by 4 AND 3
16 %% 4 == 0 & 16 %% 3 == 0

[1] FALSE

# is 16 divisible by 8 and 4 and 2
16 %% 4 == 0 & 16 %% 8 == 0 & 16 %% 2 == 0

[1] TRUE


###OR

# is 16 divisible by 4 OR 8
16 %% 4 == 0 | 16 %% 8 == 0

[1] TRUE

# is 16 divisible by 4 OR 3
# it is divisible by 4, so the answer is TRUE
# because at least one of the comparisons is TRUE
16 %% 4 == 0 | 16 %% 3 == 0

[1] TRUE




IF ELSE statements

a <- 1 # define a to be a 1
if (a == 1) {
  print(a) # this is what happens if a==1
} else {
  print("A is not 1") # this is what happens if a is not 1
}

[1] 1



a <- 2 # define a to be a 1
if (a == 1) {
  print(a) # this is what happens if a==1
} else {
  print("A is not 1") # this is what happens if a is not 1
}

[1] "A is not 1"


###IF and Else in a loop

a <- c(1, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1) # make a variable contain 1s and 0s

# write a loop to check each element in the variable
# and do different things depending on the element

for (i in a) {
  if (i == 1) {
    print("I'm a 1") # what to do when i is 1
  } else {
    print("I'm not a 1") # what to do when i is not 1
}}

[1] "I'm a 1"
[1] "I'm not a 1"
[1] "I'm a 1"
[1] "I'm not a 1"
[1] "I'm not a 1"
[1] "I'm not a 1"
[1] "I'm a 1"


###Breaking a loop

for(i in 1:10) {
  if (i < 5) {
    print(i)
  } else{
    break #Use the word break
  }
}

[1] 1
[1] 2
[1] 3
[1] 4




While loop

i <- 1 # create an variable
while (i < 6) {
  print(i)
  i = i + 1 #add one each step of the loop
}

[1] 1
[1] 2
[1] 3
[1] 4
[1] 5


###Repeat Loop

i <- 0
repeat {
  i <- i + 1
  print(i)
  if (i == 5) {
    break
  }
}

[1] 1
[1] 2
[1] 3
[1] 4
[1] 5


###Example 1 ###(Using the value of the iterator to assign in values systematically to another variable.)

# put 1 into the first five positions of x
x <- c() # create empty vector
for (i in 1:5) {
  x[i] <- 1  # assign 1 to the ith slot in x
}
x

[1] 1 1 1 1 1


###Example 2

# put the numbers 1-5 in the first 5 positions of x
x <- c()
for (i in 1:5) {
  x[i] <- i
}
x

[1] 1 2 3 4 5


###Example 3 ###Make your own counter, when you need one

a <- c(1, 4, 3, 5, 7, 6, 8, 2)
odd <- c()
counter <- 0
for (i in a) {
  # i will the values of a in each position
  counter <- counter + 1
  if (i %% 2 != 0) {
    odd[counter] <- "odd"
  } else {
    odd[counter] <- "even"
  }
}
odd

[1] "odd"  "even" "odd"  "odd"  "odd"  "even" "even" "even"

title: Week 4 Data Vis
text:
Data types: Show that you understand what is available to you in R. Note also, this goal overlaps with part of the midterm project. See the appendix on Data Types in the textbook for help. Write notes and R code chunks to demonstrate your knowledge
Tidy Data: Show that you understand what this means. Give an example of data this is in tidy format, and data that is not.
ggplot2: We will continue learning about this across the semester. Show at a minimum that you can make a graph and add it to your blog. Try examples from the textbook. Show that you understand the layer concept. Identify aspects that are confusing to you so we can discuss them in class.
Date: 02/22/23

title: Week 4 Data Vis
text:
Data.frame

my_df <- data.frame(a=1:5,
                    b = c ("one", "two", "three", "four", "five"),
                    random = runif(5,0,1))
#print to view
my_df

  a     b    random
1 1   one 0.2029983
2 2   two 0.1615871
3 3 three 0.3115725
4 4  four 0.7890571
5 5  five 0.4435256



#Access parts of the table
my_df[1,] # row 1, all columns

  a   b    random
1 1 one 0.2029983

my_df[,1] # column 1, all rows

[1] 1 2 3 4 5

my_df[1:2,3] # row 1 and 2 and column 3

[1] 0.2029983 0.1615871


#ggplot

survey_data <- read_csv("https://psyteachr.github.io/ads-v2/data/survey_data.csv")

Rows: 707 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (3): caller_id, employee_id, issue_category
dbl  (3): wait_time, call_time, satisfaction
dttm (1): call_start

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

head(survey_data)

# A tibble: 6 × 7
  caller_id employee_id call_start          wait_time call_time issue_…¹ satis…²
  <chr>     <chr>       <dttm>                  <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <dbl>
1 C001      E01         2020-09-22 10:47:54       169        34 tech           3
2 C002      E01         2020-09-07 22:10:25       206        52 tech           2
3 C003      E01         2020-07-06 12:08:59       207        41 tech           2
4 C004      E01         2020-02-20 13:12:03       132        16 tech           4
5 C005      E01         2020-11-08 17:42:10       178        20 returns        3
6 C006      E01         2020-06-01 19:06:12       230        46 returns        2
# … with abbreviated variable names ¹​issue_category, ²​satisfaction

library(tidyverse)


ggplot()



#| fig-width 250
#ggplot(data=survey_data,
       #mapping = aes(x= wait_time, y=satisfaction))
#same as above
ggplot(survey_data,aes(x= wait_time, y=satisfaction,)) + geom_point(color="black", size = 5)+ geom_point(color="blue",size= 3) + geom_smooth(method = "lm") + geom_smooth()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'




ggplot(survey_data,aes(x= wait_time, y=satisfaction, color= satisfaction)) +geom_point()

title: Week 3 Basic Skills
text:
Be able to make a new .qmd document


Copy a folder, and use a copied .qmd. Provides top lvl yml or use the green plus and press quarto docs but you start off blank. to ass yml
start with 3 dashes “---” , add title and author then end with “---



Be able to render a .qmd document


Press render at the top of the screen besides the magnifying glass icon.



Explain the difference between the source editor view and visual editor view in Rstudio.

Difference between Source and Visual in R

The source view is plain text, will be displayed exactly as it is with all the characters.
With Visual it interpenetrates it as markdown text it shows the formatted markdown text instead of the plain text.Be able to insert simple markdown plain text (headers, lists, paragraphs), and render the document.



Be able to insert simple markdown plain text (headers, lists, paragraphs), and render the document.

6. Be able to insert an R code chunk, and show the output in the rendered document.


::: {.cell}


{.r .cell-code} 1+1


::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


- macro for quick insert


- Three back ticks


- ```Shows up in a slightly different font``` produces a gray square


- To get a code block use the following to get a code block:


Command + Option + i or ```r```


::: {.cell}


{.r .cell-code} 1+1


::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


{.r .cell-code} "use /n to start a new line in a string"


::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


precedence issues (first to last)




Running R code chunks in a qmd


pressing play
copy/paste into console
highlight then command-enter (mac)
precedence issues (first to last)



Be aware of R code chunk options, and how to use eval, messages, error, warning, and echo.


#| eval: true
#| echo: true
#| error: true
hist(mtcars$mpg)






Be able to set code chunk options per chunk, and/or for the whole document. Understand rules for precedence (which options will apply if both are set.)

The value of c is 1


Write inline r code.



Explain how the rendering environment is different from the Rstudio environment.



Be aware of more advanced quarto options for html documents, and try some of the options.

title: Week 5 Data Import
text:
Week 5 Assignment

“Write your blog post, and submit the link to this assignment on blackboard. Blog post ideas will be discussed in class, and this assignment will be updated for clarity.
###Ways to view your dATA

#data() , allows you to view all the data sets
#view(cars) , allows you to view specific data sets
#print(cars) , it prints the data to the console
#glimpse(cars) , gives you a small preview of the first 10-20 data points
#head(cars) , gives you a table format of the first 10-20 data points
#summary(cars), gives basic info min, max, mean, median, 1st ,and 3rd interquartile range

###Summarytools

#library(summarytools)
# Error in loading"



Importing data

library(rio)

demo_tsv <- import(file = "data/demo.tsv") # Tab seperate factor
demo_csv  <- import("data/demo.csv")  # comma-separated values
demo_xls  <- import("data/demo.xlsx") # Excel format
demo_sav  <- import("data/demo.sav")  # SPSS format

glimpse(demo_tsv)

Rows: 6
Columns: 6
$ character <chr> "A", "B", "C", "D", "E", "F"
$ factor    <chr> "high", "low", "med", "high", "low", "med"
$ integer   <int> 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
$ double    <dbl> 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5, 6.5
$ logical   <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, NA, TRUE
$ date      <IDate> 2022-04-04, 2022-04-03, 2022-04-02, 2022-04-01, 2022-03-31, …

demo_tsv$character # does not have the concept of levels

[1] "A" "B" "C" "D" "E" "F"

demo_tsv$dactor # has the concept of levels

NULL



#Using the spec() function allows you to change or treat things as they come in.
demo<- readr::read_csv("data/demo.csv")

Rows: 6 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (2): character, factor
dbl  (2): integer, double
lgl  (1): logical
date (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

corrected_cols <- cols(
  character = col_character(),
  factor = col_factor(levels = c("low", "med", "high")), # specify the order you want
  integer = col_integer(),
  double = col_double(),
  logical = col_logical(),
  date = col_date(format = "%Y-%m-%d")
)

demo <- readr::read_csv("data/demo.csv", col_types = corrected_cols)
spec(demo)

cols(
  character = col_character(),
  factor = col_factor(levels = c("low", "med", "high"), ordered = FALSE, include_na = FALSE),
  integer = col_integer(),
  double = col_double(),
  logical = col_logical(),
  date = col_date(format = "%Y-%m-%d")
)

glimpse(demo)

Rows: 6
Columns: 6
$ character <chr> "A", "B", "C", "D", "E", "F"
$ factor    <fct> high, low, med, high, low, med
$ integer   <int> 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
$ double    <dbl> 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5, 6.5
$ logical   <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, NA, TRUE
$ date      <date> 2022-04-04, 2022-04-03, 2022-04-02, 2022-04-01, 2022-03-31, …


###Google Sheet Load Google SHeet

gs4_deauth() # skip authorisation for public data

demo_gs4  <- googlesheets4::read_sheet(
  ss = "16dkq0YL0J7fyAwT1pdgj1bNNrheckAU_2-DKuuM6aGI"
)

✔ Reading from "demo".


✔ Range 'Sheet1'.




Creating Data

avatar <- tibble( 
  name = c("Katara", "Toph", "Sokka"), # char string 
  bends = c("water", "earth", NA),
  friendly = TRUE,
  numbers = c(1,2,3),
  more_numbers = 1:3,
  even_more= seq(1,2,3)
)

# print it
avatar

# A tibble: 3 × 6
  name   bends friendly numbers more_numbers even_more
  <chr>  <chr> <lgl>      <dbl>        <int>     <dbl>
1 Katara water TRUE           1            1         1
2 Toph   earth TRUE           2            2         1
3 Sokka  <NA>  TRUE           3            3         1


###Export Data

#export(avatar, "data/avatar.csv")

###Writing Data

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Tip Sheet Week 2
text:
Date: 02/06/23
How to commit and push changes to GitHub:

Make changes to file
Render the website in R Studio
Commit the changes in GitHub desktop with a commit message
Push to github.com

(You can use R Studio as well)
Can enter a package without enabling it by using ::
beepr::beep()
Inputs to functions
beep (sound = 8, expr = NULL)
Date: 02/08/23
Use help to load the help file for functions or ?function_name Ex. ?mean to find mean function
??function_name look for functions inside of packages you have not loaded Ex. ??Mean
help (“mean”, package=“base”)
c() funtion in R my
mean(as.numeric(c(“1”,“2”,“3”))

title: Week 6 Data Summary
text:
tweets <- readRDS("ncod_tweets.rds")


library(tidyverse)

hist(tweets$favorite_count)





ggplot(tweets, aes(x=favorite_count)) + 
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.






library(dplyr)

filtered_data <- tweets%>%
  filter(favorite_count<25)
ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x=favorite_count)) + 
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.






favourite_summary <- summarise(tweets,
                           mean_favs = mean(favorite_count),
                           median_favs = median(favorite_count),
                           min_favs = min(favorite_count),
                           max_favs = max(favorite_count))


Log Scale

ggplot(tweets, aes(x = favorite_count)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) +
  scale_x_continuous(trans = "pseudo_log", 
                     breaks = c(0, 1, 10, 100, 1000, 10000))





tweet_summary <- tweets %>%
  summarise(mean_favs = mean(favorite_count),
            median_favs = quantile(favorite_count, .5),
            n = n(),
            min_date = min(created_at),
            max_date = max(created_at))

glimpse(tweet_summary)

Rows: 1
Columns: 5
$ mean_favs   <dbl> 29.71732
$ median_favs <dbl> 3
$ n           <int> 28626
$ min_date    <dttm> 2021-10-10 00:10:02
$ max_date    <dttm> 2021-10-12 20:12:27



#tweets$favorite_count

tweets$source[25]

[1] "TweetDeck"

tweets$text[54]

[1] "#NationalComingOutDay I'm trans gener bet you didn't know that.\n\nAnd if that catches you off guard wait until i tell you I'm bi and also aro"



tweet_summary <- tweets %>%
  summarise(mean_favs = mean(favorite_count),
            median_favs = quantile(favorite_count, .5),
            n = n(),
            min_date = min(created_at),
            max_date = max(created_at))

glimpse(tweet_summary)

Rows: 1
Columns: 5
$ mean_favs   <dbl> 29.71732
$ median_favs <dbl> 3
$ n           <int> 28626
$ min_date    <dttm> 2021-10-10 00:10:02
$ max_date    <dttm> 2021-10-12 20:12:27




Inline coding

date_from <- tweet_summary$min_date %>% 
  format("%d %B, %Y")
date_to <- tweet_summary$max_date %>% 
  format("%d %B, %Y")

There were 28626 tweets between 10 October, 2021 and 12 October, 2021.

tweets_per_user <- tweets %>%
  count(screen_name, sort = TRUE)

(tweets_per_user)

# A tibble: 25,189 × 2
   screen_name         n

10 Heyyitsju5tin      19
# … with 25,179 more rows



tweets_grouped <- tweets %>%
  group_by(verified)

verified <- tweets_grouped %>%
  summarise(count = n(),
            mean_favs = mean(favorite_count),
            mean_retweets = mean(retweet_count)) %>%
  ungroup()

verified

# A tibble: 2 × 4
  verified count mean_favs mean_retweets
  <lgl>    <int>     <dbl>         <dbl>
1 FALSE    26676      18.4          1.83
2 TRUE      1950     184.          21.5

title: Week 7: More gg_plot
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──
✔ ggplot2 3.4.0     ✔ purrr   1.0.1
✔ tibble  3.1.8     ✔ dplyr   1.1.0
✔ tidyr   1.3.0     ✔ stringr 1.5.0
✔ readr   2.1.3     ✔ forcats 1.0.0
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

grades <- c(2.5,8,4)
students <- c("A","B","C")

student_grades <- tibble(students, grades)

#Alternate syntax
student_grades<-tibble(
  grades =  c(2.5,8,4),
  students <- c("A","B","C")
)

ggplot(student_grades, aes(x=students, y=grades))+
  geom_bar(stat="identity",fill="white",color= "blue") + 
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = 0:10, limits= c(0,10)) +
  xlab("Students")+
  ylab("Grades")+
  ggtitle("                                                  Grades of Students")+
  geom_text(aes(label=grades),color="blue", position = position_dodge(width=1),vjust=-1) +
  theme_classic()+
  theme(title = element_text(color = "blue"))+
  theme(axis.line.x.bottom =element_line(color="blue"))+
  theme(axis.line.y.left = element_line(color="blue"))+
  theme(axis.text.x.bottom = element_text(color="blue"))+
  theme(axis.text.y.left = element_text(color="blue"))+
  theme(axis.title.y.left = element_text(color = "blue"))+
  theme(axis.title.x.bottom = element_text(color ="blue"))





Week 7 Day 2

FizzBuzz

for (i in 1:100){
  if(i %% 3 == 0 & i %% 5 == 0) {
    print("FizzBuzz")
    } 
  else if (i %% 3==0) {
    print("Fizz")
    } 
  else if (i %% 5==0) {
    print("Buzz")
    } 
  else{
    print(i)
}}

customers <- tibble(

  city = c("Port Ellen", "Dufftown", NA, "Aberlour", "Tobermory"),
  postcode = c("PA42 7DU", "AB55 4DH", NA, "AB38 7RY", "PA75 6NR")
)

  items = c(10, 18, 21, 23, 9, 11, 11, 12, 3)
)

title: Tip Sheet Week 2
text:
Date: 02/06/23
How to commit and push changes to GitHub:

Make changes to file
Render the website in R Studio
Commit the changes in GitHub desktop with a commit message
Push to github.com

(You can use R Studio as well)
Can enter a package without enabling it by using ::
beepr::beep()
Inputs to functions
beep (sound = 8, expr = NULL)
Date: 02/08/23
Use help to load the help file for functions or ?function_name Ex. ?mean to find mean function
??function_name look for functions inside of packages you have not loaded Ex. ??Mean
help (“mean”, package=“base”)
c() funtion in R my
mean(as.numeric(c(“1”,“2”,“3”))

title: Week 9
text:
Video Game Review Report





Number of reviews per year
The below histogram shows the number of video game reviews submitted to Amazon by year. From 1999 reviews largely increased year-on-year which is unsurprising given the growth of Amazon and access to the internet. The dataset shows the peak number of reviews was 2015 with a decline from 2016 to 2018. It is likely that this reflects the dataset being incomplete for recent years rather than the number of reviews declining in reality.







Day 2

title: Midterm Part 1
text:
Write a blog post where you demonstrate your ability to use these basic programming concepts in R.

R objects: show that you understand and can create/use objects of various types, including at least: character/string, numeric, integer, logical, data.frame, and list. Show that you can index objects appropriately (e.g., locate elements of an object, change elements of an object etc.)


class("This is a string") #Character

[1] "character"

class(3.5) #Numeric

[1] "numeric"

class(as.integer((3))) # Integer

[1] "integer"

my_list <- list(1,2,3,4,5) 
class(my_list) #List

[1] "list"

class(3>1) # Logical

[1] "logical"


Data Frame

# Create a data frame
sal_data<- data.frame( 
staff=c(1,2,3,4),
monthly_salary = c(4000,8000,3000,5000),
name =c("Sam", "Dan", "David", "Adam"),
age = c(23,54,18,28)
)

print(sal_data)

  staff monthly_salary  name age
1     1           4000   Sam  23
2     2           8000   Dan  54
3     3           3000 David  18
4     4           5000  Adam  28



Logical operations: show that you understand and can use logical operators in R (e.g., == | > < >= <=)


1<3  # Should = TRUE

[1] TRUE

3>1  # Should = FALSE

[1] TRUE

3==3 # Should = TRUE

[1] TRUE

1==2 # Should = FALSE

[1] FALSE

3>=3 # Should = TRUE

[1] TRUE

3<=1 # Should = FALSE

[1] FALSE

3>1 | 3<1 # Should = TRUE as only one statement has to be true "| = or"

[1] TRUE

Num = 1:10
for (i in Num)
  print(i)

Functions: Show that you understand the syntax for declaring your own function, and that you can declare and run your own custom function to accomplish some task (you choose what the function does).

Converting Pounds to Kilogram

P_to_K<-function(lbs){
  Kg<- lbs * 0.45359237 
  paste(Kg,"Kg")
  
}

P_to_K(34)

[1] "15.42214058 Kg"


Converting Kilograms to Pounds

K_to_P<-function(Kg){
  lbs<- Kg * 2.20462
  paste(lbs,"lbs")
  
}

K_to_P(10)

[1] "22.0462 lbs"

Write a function to find the sum of all integers between any two values.


Sum_sequence_loop <- function(min,max){
  a<-0
  for (i in min:max){
    a<-a+i
  }
  return(a)
}
 Sum_sequence_loop(50,100)

[1] 3825



Fizz Buzz
List the numbers from 1 to 100 with the following constraints. If the number can be divided by three evenly, then print Fizz instead of the number. If the number can be divided by five evenly, then print Buzz instead of the number. Finally, if the number can be divided by three and five evenly, then print FizzBuzz instead of the number. {r}

for (i in 1:100){
  if(i %% 3 == 0 & i %% 5 == 0) {
    print("FizzBuzz")
    } 
  else if (i %% 3==0) {
    print("Fizz")
    } 
  else if (i %% 5==0) {
    print("Buzz")
    } 
  else{
    print(i)
}}

Snakes and Ladders

roll <-sample(c(1:6),1)

total_sum<-0
num_rolls <- 0
while(total_sum < 25){
  num_rolls <- num_rolls +1
total_sum<-total_sum + roll
}
num_rolls

[1] 25



sum_rolls <- c()
for (i in 1:1000){
  total_sum<-0
  num_rolls <- 0
  while (total_sum< 25){
    num_rolls <- num_rolls +1
    total_sum <- total_sum+ sample(c(1,2,3,4,5,6),1)
  }
sum_rolls[i] <-num_rolls
}
mean(sum_rolls)

[1] 7.664



set.seed(123)
snake_and_ladders <- function(){
  square <- 0
  rolls  <- 0
  while (square < 25){
    roll <- sample(1:6, 1)
    square <- square + roll
    if (square %in% c(3, 6, 9, 10)) {
      square <- square + c(11,17,18,12)[which(c(3, 6, 9, 10) == square)]
    }
    if (square %in% c(14,19,22,24)) {
      square <- square - c(4,8,20,16)[which(c(14,19,22,24) == square)]
    }
    if (square > 25) {
      square <- square - roll
    }
    rolls <- rolls + 1
    }
return(rolls)
    }


num_interations <- 1000
results <- replicate(num_interations, snake_and_ladders())
mean(results)

[1] 15.635

title: Week 9
text:
Verified users
The dataset contains details of whether the review was based on a verified purchase. From Amazon Community

An “Amazon Verified Purchase” review means that we’ve verified that the person writing the review purchased the product from Amazon, and didn’t receive the product at a big discount. Reviews that are not marked “Amazon Verified Purchase” are valuable as well, but, either we cannot confirm that the product was purchased from Amazon, or that the customer paid a price that is available to most Amazon shoppers.




Table 1. Number of reviews by purchase status 


verified
counts




FALSE
164932


TRUE
332645
